Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Power Flow in Elastic Metamaterials: A Structural Intensity Analysis

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will introduce a novel approach that will be used to track and predict the flow of vibrational energy in elastic metamaterials with periodic and aperiodic configurations. Elastic metamaterials are artificially engineered materials designed to have mechanical properties that are not found in nature. By assembling multiple materials of different shapes and sizes in self-repeating patterns, a newly designed structure emerges that reacts uniquely to external disturbances. The ability of elastic metamaterials to block or steer propagating waves within their media enables applications which are not possible with conventional materials in vibration suppression, noise control, and acoustic cloaking. Energy-based design and performance prediction models for elastic metamaterials are currently lacking. This effort will advance the understanding of the mechanics of elastic metamaterials and will enable them to address new engineering challenges, particularly for civil infrastructure systems. This research is multidisciplinary and provides a stimulating environment for participating students to broaden their understanding of concepts pertaining to vibrations, mechanics of materials, and wave propagation.

The main objective of this research is to explore the use of concepts from Structural Intensity Analysis (SIA) to estimate power flow in multi-material (composite) dissipative metamaterials with complex geometries. The goal of this EAGER project is to lay the groundwork of using these tools in the context of metamaterials and to compare them with currently adopted wave-based models with the goal of overcoming some of their fundamental limitations. The developed mathematical framework will quantify transmission paths of vibrational energy from excitation locations to energy sinks. The analysis will facilitate the understanding of the underlying physics of band gaps and wave dispersion in metamaterials from an energy perspective. The integration of the developed tools with Bloch-wave models for elastic metamaterials will enable control over critical energy paths with the potential of confining or altering them, thus providing unprecedented opportunities for vibration control, energy harvesting, and structural adaptation, among others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project has laid the foundation of a new predictive modeling approach aimed to advance the understanding of the mechanics of elastic metamaterials and enable them to address new engineering challenges. Elastic metamaterials are artificially engineered "periodic" materials which are designed to exhibit unique wave absorption and guidance properties that cannot be otherwise achieved, rendering them potentially transformative for civil infrastructure, automotive, as well as aerospace applications. While very promising, the most common tools conventionally used to design such metamaterials exercise a number of assumptions. For example, they typically presume that a metamaterial comprises a chain of self-repeating unit cells which extends infinitely in both directions (for 1D structures) or in all directions (for 2D ones). Furthermore, they tend to overlook or oversimplify the amount, type and nature of damping of any material or viscous constituent. As a result, while useful at the preliminary design stage, such tools do not lend themselves well for the design, understanding, and experimental synthesis of realistic metamaterial configurations.

Over the course of this project, the PI and the accompanying team established the use of a mathematical framework, referred to as the Structural Intensity Analysis (SIA), aiming to fundamentally address the aforementioned limitations. The SIA is an energy-based approach which provides graphical representations of the primary structural power flow paths within a metamaterial when subject to different excitations and disturbances. By quantifying the dominant transmission paths of vibrational energy from excitation locations to energy sinks, we were able to develop an understanding and a robust physical interpretation of the underlying mechanics of band gaps (i.e. regions of forbidden propagations), wave dispersion, and other metrics of interest in dissipative metamaterials - albeit from an energy perspective. Furthermore, the integration of the SIA with currently adopted models for elastic metamaterials enabled us to achieve a level of control over critical energy paths with the goal of confining, steering, absorbing or altering them to fit a prescribed need or application, thus providing unprecedented opportunities in vibration mitigation, noise control, and energy regulation. The previous features were illustrated experimentally through a series of tests involving a class of "locally resonant" metamaterial plates. The experimental investigations were used to identify "hot spots" or regions of high energy concentration and elevated vibrational amplitudes. This signaled the importance of taking necessary steps to avoid structural failure (e.g. reinforcement, supports, etc) to account for increased energy flow to specific regions of the structure as a result of heavy absorption elsewhere.

The project had a number of broader societal impacts including the training of several graduate students, as well as an undergraduate student as part of NSF's "Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU)" program. The student trained as part of this project was recently recognized by the Dean's Undergraduate Achievement Award for Research Excellence in 2017-2018. The project was also used as a seed for a new graduate offering at the University at Buffalo (UB) in the Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering department, as well as a platform for a professional internship for a doctoral student as part of NSF's "Non-Academic Research Internships for Graduate Students (INTERN)" program.
